showScoreExcerpt:
While the fundamentals—plot, situation, circumstances—of Jaja’s African Hair Braiding are more or less familiar, the details of the world it presents (its so-called “local color”) are what make it work. The characters, their concerns (especially regarding living in America, including legal status), their appearances, and their language, all contribute to the creation of a world unfamiliar to most Broadway theatergoers, but which, judging from the audience’s enthusiastic response, are greatly appreciated.
